statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: The performance of Andre Miller and  re-emergence of Quentin Richardson provided a huge lift for the Los Angeles Clippers.
article.headline: Miller's timely 3 caps monster game, forces OT
article.linkText: Miller (37 points, 16 assists) does it all as Clips trip Nets
article.story:
LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Andre Miller grimaced as he described his game-tying 3-pointer with 4.9 seconds left in the fourth quarter -- a shot he believed to be far off the mark.
Miller

Fortunately for the Los Angeles Clippers, Miller's assessment was incorrect. And that was one of the few mistakes he made Thursday night. Miller had 37 points to equal a career high along with a season-high 16 assists, and Elton Brand made a three-point play to put the Clippers ahead for good in a 126-118 overtime victory over the New Jersey Nets. "When it left my hand, I thought it was going to go past the rim,'' Miller said of his big 3-pointer, which tied the game at 111 and forced overtime. "Man, he was amazing, hitting shot after shot,'' Brand said of Miller, who shot 14-of-24, including 2-of-5 from 3-point range, and had only one turnover in 48 minutes. Brand, who had 21 points, eight rebounds and four blocked shots, put the Clippers on top 118-116 with 3:02 left. Michael Olowokandi, who had 14 points, nine rebounds and five blocks, made four free throws in the final minute to clinch the victory. Miller, acquired from Cleveland during the offseason, called the game the best the Clippers have played this season. "We played well, we finished off the game the way we needed to,'' he said. "Tonight was a night we were able to get to the basket and make plays. I was able to get guys involved in key situations and they were able to knock down shots. "We played a good game all-around -- offensively and defensively.'' Eric Piatkowski had 17 points and Quentin Richardson added 14 points and eight rebounds for the Clippers. Jason Kidd had 35 points, including all seven for the Nets in overtime, along with eight rebounds and eight assists. He made a 3-pointer early in overtime -- the Nets' franchise-record 15th -- to give New Jersey a 114-113 lead. Another basket by Kidd made it 116-115 before Brand's big three-point play. "We had a great opportunity in overtime, we just couldn't close it out,'' Kidd said. "It was a game that we should have won, but unfortunately, it's not over until it's over.'' Kerry Kittles added 19 points, Richard Jefferson had 17 points and 11 rebounds and Lucious Harris also scored 17 for the Nets. After Miller's game-tying basket, Kidd missed an off-balance shot from about 18 feet as the fourth quarter ended. "I thought it was a good shot, I had a good look,'' he said. "Unfortunately, it didn't go in. But we didn't win or lose the game on that play.'' Two free throws by Kidd with 8.3 seconds left gave the Nets a 111-108 lead. "It hurts,'' Nets coach Byron Scott said of the loss. "You've got to give them credit, they did almost everything perfect.'' Miller's three-point play with 5:02 remaining capped a 15-0 run in a span of nearly four minutes that put the Clippers on top 101-96. It was Miller's second three-point play during the spurt. "I thought he played great -- simple as that,'' Scott said. But the Nets battled back, outscoring the Clippers 15-7 before Miller's tying 3-pointer. Kittles made three 3-point shots in the first 5:12 of the third quarter to help the Nets extend a 54-50 halftime lead to 69-59. Kidd's 3-pointer with 2.1 seconds left in the period made it 85-77. Harris outscored the Clippers by himself 11-6 in a span of 3:16 to give the Nets a 51-46 lead late in the second period. Coming off a season-low 29.5 percent shooting performance at Phoenix, the Nets made their first four shots to take a 9-0 lead in the opening 84 seconds. Kidd hit the first two -- the second from 3-point range. Los Angeles missed six shots and trailed 11-0 before Miller made a jumper. Miller added 11 more points and the Clippers made 12 of their last 16 shots in the first quarter for a 30-29 lead.

Game notes
The Nets had beaten the Clippers five straight times, including a 106-92 decision Nov. 8 in New Jersey and a 95-90 triumph last Thanksgiving at Staples Center. ... The Clippers have led in the fourth quarter in 13 of their 16 games, but have only six wins. "We're just not finishing games,'' coach Alvin Gentry said. That wasn't the case in this game. ... The Nets' horrific 26-of-88 shooting effort including 4-of-19 from 3-point range Wednesday night in an 82-75 loss to the Suns came 13 years to the day after the all-time franchise low of 25.5 percent (25-of-98) at Utah. ... "They're not going to shoot 29 percent tonight,'' Gentry predicted beforehand. He was right -- the Nets made 46.8 percent (44-of-94) and went 15-of-29 from 3-point range. ... The game marked the 1,800th Clippers broadcast by Ralph Lawler, in his 24th year as the team's play-by-play announcer.
